big name, you know, we've talked about that. Or when we had, you know, David Smalley on the podcast,
like things that new information that we know that he's experienced in our relationships with him,
it's like it never happened. Like he's, he's still discussing arguments that, that we engaged with.
And really that he even acknowledged were not great arguments a decade ago. They're still there.
It's like they didn't penetrate. And I'm, I'd like to think I've got all new conversations
10 years later. Um, and some of it impacted by him, but you know, even what you said earlier about
one of the things we discovered, I don't know if you've listened to those on this podcast yet,
Mark, but it was intriguing that one of the things we discovered with him was him saying
that where he went to church and in his family, he wasn't allowed to ask questions like this.
Right. Right. And you're like, wow, that just breaks your heart. So anyway, that's part of what
we're passionate about this podcast for is people learning to deconstruct their faith and then
reconstruct is as in a healthy way. Anyway, but yeah, I agree with you. I feel like I'm, I'm always
bummed when I read an atheist and I get excited about them. And then they start talking about,
you know, Jesus is just one of the Egyptian gods, you know, plagiarized and you're like, no,
no, it's not. We've got that research. That's been debunked. Why are you still there?
That's true. So you were saying then the dogmatic ones who are, you can, who are clearly
closed-minded, those aren't really shaking or don't really, yeah. Hold a candle to your faith.
Yeah. Well, yeah, to continue your thought, keep going.
No, that's great. And yes, I would say, yeah, there's different like specific questions that
have I've had to like deconstruct or think about, but dad, you mentioned Jordan Peterson. I know you
wanted to meet you wanted me to touch on this bit. So he's kind of for our listeners, if they don't
know, he's a he is a clinical physician or sorry, a psychiatrist, clinical psychiatrist with his PhD
from Toronto, Canada. And he's a professor or was a professor in Toronto. I think I don't know if
he's still technically, I think he's a psychologist, not a psychiatrist. Just so I think he is a
psychiatrist. So clinical psychologist, and he's written a few books. But mainly his discussion
unpacking biblical stories from the Old Testament in a psychological way, is what partially made
him go viral, and made him explode into the public eye. So his his his lectures on Genesis,
have like, tens of millions of views. And basically, it's him for like two hours lecturing about the
deep psychology of biblical texts. He also became famous because he put his foot down and said, I
won't abide by Canada's new laws, which are forcing speech on me. And that speech was to use
the correct pronouns for trans people. I think that's a that's a whole different debate that
I've just wrote like a 30 page white paper on that will publish soon. But like, regardless of where
you stand on that, like he's even said, you know, maybe I will use pronouns for certain people,
but the laws forcing me to say something is what he stood up against and said, I won't do it.
So since then, he's become huge. And so for a couple of years, he basically did a lot of videos
and podcasts with great thinkers. So I went down what's called, you know, a rabbit hole, and was
organizing Jim, Dr. Dennison's library of 7000 books. And, and I was just listening to hour after
hour after hour of Jordan Peterson's talks. And he truly is like an interesting intellectual,
because he does philosophy. But he's a, he's a clinical psychologist. So he has a unique insight
into things. Recently, he's become more of a voice of conservatism. So he's talked less on existential
personal questions, and has since started focusing more on policy, and conservatism in general.
I kind of hit him in his philosophy stage, that makes sense. And what it made me do was I knew he
didn't believe in God, quote unquote, but he did believe in God as this kind of like, this is a
standard for morality that we all need to believe in. Because it helps us live better lives. And so
he was coming at it almost from a therapist's point of view. And to me, he gave a lot of good context
to the Bible that was like really deep. And so I was intrigued by it. And really what my wrestling
came down to was, where do I disagree with him? Because it seems to me that everything he says is
so persuasive, I can't help but agree. And one of his beliefs is basically like, you know, his
classic response, people would always ask him, Do you believe in God? You know, like, what do you
do you believe in God? Yes or no. And he would say, What do you even mean by that question? Is what his
response, I mean, he would be like, What do you mean, God? Like, if I believed in God, do you mean
that I behave as though God existed? And he said, if yes, then I try to. But the kind of weight that
actually truly believing in God would bring to your life would be so overwhelming. That would be like
impossible to uphold, basically. Wow. And so I don't know if he switched his views, because recently
he's been talking with Jewish rabbis, like in New Testament and Old Testament scholars of the Christian
faith a lot, having those conversations, which I haven't dug into a lot, but they seem interesting.
But I think he still maintains this kind of agnosticism about literally, quote unquote,
whether God is real. And I think what I realized is my, you know, he would provide the same kind of
psychological analysis of what was that movie? Pinocchio. He was kind of made fun of this, but like,
he did like an hour long lecture on the psychology of Pinocchio. So in a way, he's treating the Bible
with a lot of respect, like this is the most sacred document in the West. And this has a lot of wisdom
to give us. But he's also doing something similar with Pinocchio. And so I think something to me
that opened my eyes was this is where I disagree with him. I literally believe in a personal God.
And two, I believe in the gospel, which is something that he doesn't really have a framework for.
So that's where I realized, okay, I disagree with him there. And I began to see the need for the
truth of the gospel, in addition to his intellectual analysis of the Bible. Yep. So that's where I've
landed. But that was a challenge for you. Yeah, totally. Yeah, it wasn't easy.
Because that's a tough, I mean, when we read people like that, and we respect them,
and we have a high opinion of them, and they have, at least at this stage, reached a different
conclusion than us. I mean, that's understandably troubling, for lack of a better word. Because it
feels like I'm saying, I am not as smart as this person. And yet, I've reached a different conclusion.
And that feels, I don't know, arrogant or something maybe to us. And I think every,
what I found is helpful for listeners is everyone you get a source of information from
will be wrong at some point. So I think what I discovered was, you know, I think that
whether it's you dad, which would be the first to admit, or anyone else you respect, there will
become if you don't, if you haven't had the moment where you say, wait, I think that's off,
or I think that's not right. If you haven't had that moment yet, then you will. And if you don't
for a long time, that probably means you're like, idolizing, or you're not really filtering it.
And that's, that's true of like theologians. That's true. You know, I don't know, like, I,
I really love a theologian named N.T. Wright. Yeah. And, you know, I got on like a track with him,
where I was listening to him a lot. And I don't remember anything specific, where I ended up
saying I disagree. I mean, he's an Anglican. So I think there's some things it's, it's very few
things, but I think there's a couple of theological things who disagree on, you know, infant baptism
or something. Right. But yeah, I think like everyone you have to come to grips with in some
way is going to be wrong. And that's where the humility comes into play. I think that's scary
for people, which is interesting. So I've said for years, you know, you'll hear me say this,
and I will say, I don't, you know, when I say, Oh, you ought to go read, you know, for example,
N.T. Wright's book about the Apostle Paul, I'm like, Oh my gosh, this thing is so good. Isn't
he the one who wrote the biography on Paul recently? Yeah, he was. And I was like, this is, this is
brilliant. Now I don't agree with everything he says. And then if you've ever heard me speak
many times, you know that I have a little catchphrase almost there. Like, I don't agree with
everything he says, but then I don't agree with everything I say. Like I go back and listen to
sermons and talks and read stuff I've written them like, Oh yeah, that wasn't very good. Or no,
that was a mistake. I actually, I told somebody it was a huge gift to me that in my Summa Theologica,
the seminary, my final big theological paper, I committed what would be considered a heresy
by me today. And yet I wrote it into my main theological final paper in seminary. So I got
to start right off not having too much confidence in my own abilities to recognize, wow, I can,
I can actually really argue something, defend something and believe something that,
that just a few years later, I would say, yeah, that was totally wrong, completely wrong. And so
that's again, why we come back to deconstructing our faith in ourselves is usually a healthy
part of the process. Mark, did I give you a copy of the low, low anthropology book?
Anthropology. I don't know if you guys thinking about mentioning that I've read it. It's fantastic.
Is it? I knew it would be good. That guy's that, wow, I'm just suddenly blinking on his name. He's
someone who we want to have on the podcast. Yeah, exactly. And he's, we're gonna, we're gonna have
him later on next month. Okay. Fantastic. And I thought it was so, it was such a great one. I,
when I heard it, so I didn't get to read it yet, but I heard him teach the material
directly. And I was like, this, this is healthy deconstruction. Yeah. Anyway, so we'll, I'll be
fascinated for us to get to hear his perspective on that. But that's what I was thinking too,
as well. So Mark, kind of going back to your story and, you know, obviously you and, and,
you know, your dad talking about this as well. You, you seem to have a healthy relationship
with doubt or, or things that like might, might call your faith or what you believe into question,
but it's not an earth shaking thing. It's more like an exciting, Oh, let's explore this.
Kind of a thing where other people might be, I mean, legitimately scared and then, but then
not move forward in that when you were in college, did you find that a lot of people had
the same mentality as you did as far as, you know, you're going through these philosophical
differences that if, if you don't, if you don't take an approach to, or like, if you're,
if your mindset is more of a fear-based fearful, I can't ask these questions. I can't, you know,
I can't think through these and, you know, in a critical way. I just don't like is in, in the
philosophical sphere, is that like, if you come in as a Christian, and I know you went to a Baptist
university, but still, did you find that a lot of people kind of had a similar mentality as you
of like, Hey, we're, we're not gonna, we're not gonna leave this alone as far as our faith,
but we are going to ask these hard questions. Or do you feel like this mentality is, is kind of rare?
Well, I would say it's rare. But again, as you mentioned, I went to back to school, and what I
ended up doing, not on purpose, but just naturally, was my best friends were almost always creatives.
And so they were in graphic design, they were doing music, they were, and some of them, yeah,
they're something else you have to remember at DBU was that the philosophy program was very small.
And so a couple of people in there were my friends. But honestly, like, we didn't really
bond around philosophy that much. I actually bonded around philosophy with people who weren't
philosophy students. Yeah. And yeah, all of them had really, I think good relationships without like,
they were maybe not all of them had as much as many like boundaries, where they,
you know, I think I would be more committed to a
Orthodox position, and not all of them were. But it was really great. I think if you surround
yourself with those people like they exist. And I wish I had more chances to talk with people who
did doubts who, in an unhealthy way, or who questioned their faith, or who left their faith,
like I didn't get a chance to do that very much because of my schooling, because of where I went
to school, and because of the friends I surrounded myself with. So I don't know the answer to your
question, kind of like yes and no. But I think that probably very few people have a good
relationship with doubt in college. It's just, I went to a back to school, and all my friends were
Christians who loved to talk about those things. So they tended to have a good relationship with it.
That's good. Bryn, do you have any thoughts?
I just had a, like my passing thought was, I think it's so healthy to,
even if it's rare, just developing that, I mean, you naturally are an inquisitive person, but I
think even for people who aren't developing that desire to seek truth and ask those hard questions,
I think the younger the age that we develop that, and then if we're at an age where it's not as
natural to try to get back to that with humility. You know, Chris, you've said that the problem with,
we've said this multiple times, but the problem with midlife crisis is we only have them,
you know, we don't have them often enough. I think it's been early and often.
Yeah, have them early and often is what I tell people.
Yeah, but my husband and I were talking the other day about how often it seems like the older we get,
if we are not conscious of this practice, especially if it doesn't come naturally to us,
we just become more and more set in the things that we think because it's comfortable and sometimes
there's a pride associated with it or laziness, like whatever is there. And so I think, yeah,
that was just a thought that I had of like the more often we can cultivate this mindset,
I think is so healthy and like you were saying, is a humility that we need our whole lives. And
so I don't know, that was just a thought of like, even if it's rare, I think it's something that
if it does come naturally, people should lean into it. And if it doesn't, it's something they
should actively try to cultivate just that inquisitive mindset of asking hard questions.
And like Chris is saying, admitting like, yeah, I'm going to lean into seeking for truth,
but I am also capable of being wrong at any point. And I think that mindset is
so healthy, but countercultural to our sin a lot of times, you know,
what interesting comment, the thought that it could be our flesh that sometimes makes us settle
into an unhealthy relationship with even with our own faith, that it's just laziness or fear
or comfort that keeps us from pride, that keeps us from being willing to have the conversation.
And I don't, I'd said before, I don't think it's healthy for everybody depending on their stage
of where they are in their faith. Like it's not healthy for everybody depending on their stage to
read a book by one of these leading atheists yet. But the goal would be to get to a place in our
faith where we're sophisticated enough, if I can use that word, meaning the technical, the wise
enough, Sophia, that we're wise enough in our understanding that we can read it and go, okay,
wow, there were three questions in there that I would have no idea how to answer.
But rather than panic, rather than panic and freak out, as Chris Sherry likes to say, like,
this may be my first time to ask this question, but I'll bet it's not the first time it's been asked.
And so let me do some work and figure out. And it is so comforting the first few times. I know it's
scary when you do that at first and you discover something and you kind of had this, I mean,
I've had it many times in my life where I have this sinking feeling of like, if that's true,
that may undermine the most important thing in my life. But okay, don't panic. If it's true,
I still need to believe it and change my life if that's what it requires. So calmly,
let's dig into this. And then what happens is when I have, at least obviously in my life,
discovered like, oh, like we'd some with, we talked about Chris Sherry, sometimes it's
that he's still like, oh, that's just like, not factually true. Like, right. That just turned out
to be inaccurate. Okay, good. I don't know. Okay. I can let go of that. Or you discover,
okay, that's an excellent point, but there's also been other brilliant thinkers who have
worked through that. And here's the conclusion they've reached. So, or there's an equally
difficult question in the same category that goes the other direction. And so anyway, it's just,
it's been fascinating. And that's over time, I've learned to love almost like a weird version of
an adrenaline junkie, I guess, to hear that question and go, oh, that's going to be so cool
when I dig into that. And so far, as Billy Graham said, the gospel is the anvil around which the
hammers lay broken. And that has certainly been my experience in life is that, I now get fascinated
when I think there's a new case for atheism. And I want to learn it because, you know,
it's intriguing to me. And I don't, I don't, I no longer have a fear, although I recognize it as
plausible, I guess, or possible, maybe not plausible, but possible that there is going to
be something that would change that view. But if that's the case, then a God of truth would want me
to change my, you know, the God who I worship would want me to believe the truth. And that feels,
that feels weird and contradictory, but it's, it's also super comforting, at least to me.
Sure. So yeah, go ahead.
Well, I was just gonna say, I also think your comment about even if someone's an expert, like,
a, they can be wrong. And it doesn't mean that every aspect of their life, they're right about
things. And I think as a culture, we have a tendency to do that. Where if someone's an expert
in one area, that we think that they have true, like a, you know, monopoly on truth in every area,
for some reason, you know, if some, even if they are a professional, you know, like, I mean, take
the acting industry, or an extreme example of someone is a professional in one way, oh, they
must have a handle on truth and all these other areas that they're speaking into. And that's like,
extreme example. But I think we do that as culture. And I think it's even comforting to me,
and such a good reminder to hear that of even if someone is, is very intelligent, that doesn't mean
that they are not wrong about things. And, and I think that was such a wise statement.
Yeah, yeah. And there's, there's like, as an example of that, I know you guys, and I'll say
something else about this too. But, you know, Richard Dawkins, God Delusion is a great example
of that, because he is a leading evolutionary biologist at Oxford, right? He is the real deal
for that. Or even someone like Neil deGrasse Tyson, like, I think he's the real deal, like in astronomy,
like he is like legit. But like you said, we think that that has. But Richard Dawkins book,
God Delusion was a bit of an embarrassment to Oxford, I think, because yeah, it's publicly like,
it's it was it was made to be accessible for the average person. So to be fair, at the same time,
there was like a quote I read recently of someone who knew Dawkins personally. And he was like,
I know for a fact that Dawkins reads very little philosophy and even less theology. And like,
he doesn't know anything about like, he's not an expert in theology or philosophy at all.
And so the arguments he made in the God Delusion, which led a lot of people to a certain conclusion,
was just fallacious, like downright, obviously fallacious. But the second thing is, I think
that's part of why, when we talk about deconstruction now, it's there's a there's a great saying,
I think I read this first in a work by like Barna, the Barna Institute,
the I think it was like in the Gen Z book, I think you guys have even read it, right? The Gen Z book
by Barna. Yeah, yeah. So there's one quote where basically it says Gen Z confuses being judgmental
with making judgments. And that's so well said, I think, instead of being judgmental is wrong.
But making judgments about truth or about the morality of something is not. And the difference
between those things has a lot of differences. But it's just interesting for me to know that I think
where people are rejecting their faith is not because they're attracted to a Dawkins type
atheism. Right. It's not. Young people are attracted to an open mindedness that says any judgments that
are made can't overrule someone's own perspective, someone's like personal perspective, basically.
And the part of that is because I think of the internet, there's so many, there's so much you
can basically shop for ideas for ever. Yeah, on the internet. And so the question becomes so
difficult, in fact, impossible to answer of different questions of truth that you just shrug
and say, well, whatever works for you. So I think that is much more of the threat rather than,
you know, and kind of hardline and hardnose atheism. Yeah, yeah. I think that's, I think
that's a really good thought. Yeah, I agree. Really good thought. I think a lot of people don't.
I like it. I think it's very often that you'll have someone who says, you know, that they were
convinced by an argument by someone like a Dawkins or a Bart Ehrman or Sam Harris. But then when you
talk with them, I'm not convinced they've read the book. Right. Because they're not reaching the
same conclusions. They don't have the same cases. They don't have the same arguments. And I agree,
I think that the Dawkins version of atheism is, I would say profoundly weak and not something that
most people would be interested in if they knew what he believes and the consequences of it.
You know, that's a, I agree with that. And I think though, you're right that the thought that
being a Christian though, means your judgment, your judgmental, and being an atheist means
you're open-minded. And that's as far as the conversation has gone. Therefore, I'm an atheist
because or an agnostic because, because I'm open-minded and open-minded. Who am I to say that
somebody else's opinion is wrong? And it's like, well, I think you have a high opinion of everybody's
opinion. The data bears out that young people are, because you guys have read that book, like
they are less religious, more spiritual. Yes. Like, so it's not even that they're atheists.
I don't think basically none of them would claim to be atheists. Like atheism has stayed very steady
for a very long time. It's like 7%. Like, yeah, it's up a tiny bit, maybe like 1% or something,
but it's pretty steady. But, but irreligious has grown. And I think that's just because,
I don't know. Yeah. I mean, we could go down that rabbit hole as to why, but basically just to state
that and put it out there. I don't think that's a huge, that's big of a threat.
You know, unless you're going into like sciences where that's that bias does exist.
But yeah. Okay. All of that. Well, Mark, thank you for sharing your story. I really appreciate that.
There's some really good insight and I think will help people, one, if they're parents or if they're
people walking into seasons that, you know, where it's like, okay, the potential here for asking
hard questions, maybe that you haven't gone through is high. And so I just think of a lot of people
that I've talked to who are parents wanting to help their own children. It's really cool to hear,
like, okay, what are things that we can start doing now to cultivate this idea of hard questions
aren't wrong. And what is best is to search for answers. I think that's really good.
What a great confirmation for us to even hear some of that. And it's, I feel like that's becoming
a pattern, guys, is this people who are allowed to engage with these hard questions in a way that
the adults, the leaders, the teachers around them aren't afraid. That is, that is a high, at least
an art limited, our limited data set. That's been a high correlation for people who are holding fast
in a time of when many people around them are deconstructing is that they've had the freedom to
grow in their doubt and to face challenges and doubts in a healthy way. That's really good.
And maybe in the next episode, we can hear some more about the things that anchor Mark,
that anchor you to your faith. When you do have those, I think most of us have those that when
we face those moments of like, uh, what if that to go, okay, okay, what do I fall back on? Where do
I find my, okay, but then I'd have to answer this and I don't have another answer for that.
Yeah. So maybe we can come back to that next time. Super. Yeah. Thanks Mark. That's been great.
Thank you guys.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of reconstructed faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed,
shoot me an email at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed faith is a resource of South
Spring Baptist church. Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
